questions.question_text: A software company is hosting a seminar at a local conference center to unveil its latest software release. As the clients begin to arrive and connect their mobile devices to the wireless network, users begin to report connectivity and throughput issues. Which of the following should the network technicians do to resolve the reported issues quickly?

comments.content:
"Which of the following should the network technicians do to resolve the reported issues quickly?"

This is the quickest solution, especially considering there's an event, you're not going to install and config new network equipment in that type of scenario, you're going to call the ISP and come to an agreement on speed. 
The keyword here is "quickly"

discussion.content: I'm having trouble visualizing an ISP as "quick." By the time they get extra bandwidth, the event will be over.

comments.content: I dont think it would take that long...when I bought a new HD TV which required more bandwidth it only took me a few minutes on the phone to get it increased...so imagine your a business and need to get yours increased...it wont take to long compared to the other choices provided

choices.D: Upgrade the wireless network to the newest standard.
choices.A: Call the ISP to increase the bandwidth.
choices.C: Run Cat 6 cable to each of the WAPs.

discussion.content:
An ARP spoofing, also known as ARP poisoning, is a Man in the Middle (MitM) attack that allows attackers to intercept communication between network devices. The attack works as follows:

The attacker must have access to the network. They scan the network to determine the IP addresses of at least two devices⁠—let’s say these are a workstation and a router. 
The attacker uses a spoofing tool, such as Arpspoof or Driftnet, to send out forged ARP responses. 
The forged responses advertise that the correct MAC address for both IP addresses, belonging to the router and workstation, is the attacker’s MAC address. This fools both router and workstation to connect to the attacker’s machine, instead of to each other.
The two devices update their ARP cache entries and from that point onwards, communicate with the attacker instead of directly with each other.
The attacker is now secretly in the middle of all communications.

ARP spoofing is a Man In The Middle (MITM) attack in which the attacker (hacker) sends forged ARP Messages. This allows the attacker to pretend as a legitimate user as it links the attacker machine's MAC Address to the legitimate IP Address

questions.question_text: Which of the following protocols do MOST MITM attacks utilize?

A client utilizes mobile tablets to view high-resolution images and videos via WiFi within a corporate office building. The previous administrator installed multiple high-density APs with WiFi 5, providing maximum coverage, but the measured performance is still below expected levels. Which of the following would provide the
BEST solution?

discussion.content:
What is channel bonding? The 802.11b and 802.11g wireless
standards use a single channel to send and receive information. With channel
bonding, you can use two channels at the same time. As you might guess, the
capability to use two channels at once increases performance. Bonding can help
increase wireless transmission rates from the 54 Mbps offered with the 802.11g
standards to a theoretical maximum of 600 Mbps with 802.11n.

questions.question_text: A rural municipality has built an external public WiFi meshed network using omnidirectional antennas. After the initial build, the performance meets expectations, and the municipality enters a six-month pilot program in the fall. By the end of the pilot program in the spring, the performance has fallen dramatically. The pilot has a static number of users with no increases in usage from beginning to end. Which of the following would be the MOST likely reason for the performance issues?

discussion.content: This one actually made me laugh out loud. Im curious if anybody has gotten this question
im from equator country, i dont know this
the only foliage that 99.99% of any of us in the field are going to encounter is a potted plant on someone's office desk and I cant say that it would ever be an issue

comments.content: If leaves fall, then why would it add to absorption issues? CompTIA trying to be too clever, or a misquoted question?
That's some bullshit LMAO, we need to know when plants BLOOM??
It's common sense to know fall - leaves fall down. Spring - leaves grow back.

choices.A: Too many users in the pilot creating overcapacity issues
choices.C: Omnidirectional antennas being insufficient for outdoor use

questions.question_text: Which of the following should a technician use to keep the STP topology predictable and consistent?

discussion.content: "Root guard is an STP feature that is enabled on a port-by-port basis; it prevents a configured port from becoming a root port. Root guard prevents a downstream switch (often misconfigured or rogue) from becoming a root bridge in a topology." - from ciscopress.com
